posts.name: Anonymous

>>17419910
well I am almost done building these 2 test plates. Some hasguns offered to shoot them for me. Results should come soon. They're build like the armor, rigid, laminated with epoxy. Which gives me an idea to make a third test panel, consisting of only 12 layers of the thinner fibreglass, without any adherement.

About aramid, it's 10 times as expensive compared to various different types of fibreglass. Fibreglass comes in different weaves and weights per m2. I used two types, a heavy kind called woven roving, large strands weighing about 500 - 800 g/m2 (ebay descriptions are always a bit iffy) and a light, tightly woven glass weighing in on 160 - 240 or so g/m2. 10m2 of either of that stuff costs about 30€, aramid in that quantity around 300€+.

My greatest fear about making friends is that i feel i will be forcing the relationship. And what if they dont even like me?
The only reason i mention this cal group is because as i mentioned they are similar to my old friends and they share somewhat similar interests to me (namely vidya, music (bands i dont actively listen to but like), and even though i dont watch a lot, anime. Some of them work out too but im still a skinny dyel). To make friends with anyone else here seems like an insurmountable wall.
Yet i dont know how to talk to them without coming across as weird. I thought i could wait for a chance to say something during the semester if they were having a conversation about a topic i like but the chance never really came, and when it did i couldnt think of anything to say.
So ive probably already cemented myself as a shy autist in their minds, or at the very least weird.
I feel like i have more than enough to make friends here but i dont know how to take the first step.
When you made friends, did it just happen? Or did you have to work for it? Or a mix of both?
And where can i learn how to make friends?
I always hear "look for clubs on campus" but i genuinely think theres none here. The closest thing i can think of was my cal teacher holding after-class meetings in a nearby room for help with math homework. Which i didnt need because i already took a highschool class of cal 1 and 2 (it wasnt a college credit type thing but it helped me immensely this past semester and will help this next semester).
But it felt awkward getting my tests and quizzes back and seeing 95s-100s while everyone around me was lucky to get an 80. I saw the guy sitting in front of me trying to glance back at one of my test grades. Wonder what he thinks of me.
I feel terrible for never offering help. I think they all passed, the 11 other people left in the class.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17420550
>Armaf Niche Oud
Ambery, warm frag. There are some spices but I can't really detect them. Supposedly a clone of Ambre Sultan, although I haven't tried it. The drydown reminds me a bit of Bentley for Men Intense, although I get an incensey church vibe from it. Very good longevity and great sillage for hours. I just have a decant and I still haven't finished it in over a year. Just 1-3 sprays is more than enough.
>Mancera Sahara Wind
Leathery, slightly spicy, soapy. Reminds me of a old man's shaving soap in a good way. Less projection and longevity but still above average to me.
>Kenzo Jungle
Fresh, woody/spicy frag, a little powdery to my nose. I get a note that I can't really explain (could be the mate or guaiac wood) which I haven't really smelled before but it does smell nice. Decent for warm weather but I've never worn it on a very hot day. This is the lightest frag in terms of projection but still a decent performer and does last a long time on my skin, although I go heavier on the sprays.

https://www.fragrantica.com/perfume/Etat-Libre-d-Orange/Une-Amourette-Roland-Mouret-46517.html

Anyone else worn this? I picked up a bottle after getting a sample in my Luckyscent order. It's another fragrance that heavily features Akaigalawood but it doesn't smell like Ganymede,BI, or Kenzo Intense at all. Roland is more of a fuzzy, musky fragrance with Oud and florals coated with a candied vanilla shell.

I find it fascinating how this fragrance features more "delicate" ingredients than the other tree but the Akaigalawood doesn't overpower them and make itself the center of attention here.
If you're looking for an interesting unisex fragrance that doesn't quite smell like anything else out there, give Roland a shot

A brief list:
1: Reselling bottles of Aventus as real Aventus when his partner took photos of him refilling empty Aventus bottles with clone juice. I have no idea why the fuck he took a picture but it got released, he denied it even though it's a literal fucking pic of him doing it lol

2: Releasing clones that often cost more per ml than the original frags do. Small brain shit skins see $65 dollars and know that's a smaller number than $200 and so they know that the prophet Mohammed praise be upon him is helping them save money. But they are too stupid to figure out that if you buy a bottle at reseller prices or at grey market you get the original actual fragrance for cheaper cost /ml

3: Their whole stick is the high percentage of oils. Well,turns out that's a sort of half truth. Multiple turbo autists ran DUA and Alexandria fragrances through shit like gas chromatography and other tests and then released the results. Turns out that yes the fragrance may technically be an extrait strength due to oil percentage but the bulk of the oils were inert carrier oils like jojoba. So the actual percent of fragrant oils is at EDT levels at best, rarely EDP. Never extrait.

But they leave a greasy smear on your skin so small brain pajeets "know" that means more oil and more oil means better so they gobble the swill up.


4: Social media shills and bullies. This is more the fault of the whole influencer system but if you suck them off they will bury your channel in free shit even if five people watch you, but if you give even a vaguely honest review or commentary the fan boy accounts will come out of the wood work to harass you, and for extra fun sometimes they harass your family to.
And by fan boys I mean the actual owners too, dumb fucks did this multiple times forgetting they were logged in to their own accounts.

5: What makes other clone brands better? The fact they shut the fuck up and operate quietly without pretending they are gods gift to perfumery.

In America there's a common cliche about how neckties are like nooses. Gen X got the idea into their heads that the white collar worker was oppressed and that the tie was a symbol of his slavery. What followed was a forceful and enduring rejection of traditional menswear under the pretense that no one would willingly wear it. This is why the whole "you're awfully dressed up, got a job interview?" meme exists.

And thanks, it's my favorite tie. I just got this wool one recently that I really like as well. Goes great with a brown suit and a blue shirt. Cost me $24.99 on clearance. Brooks Brothers bankruptcy, the pandemic and cultural change combined to leave a ton of their old inventory orphaned. It's starting to get thin but you can still go into any thrift store in America and walk out with a high quality fashionable used tie for $1.99.

I struggle with shirts a lot. I lock myself into fairly tame solids for fear of having difficulty coordinating. I've got half a dozen plain white shirts. It does make it so that more interesting ties have room to breathe though.

Post some of your ties. 60+ is a lot.

The only thing that matters for looking good is everything about your person looking as proportionally flattering as possible, which is quantifiable by way of an ideal 'contextually appropriate' ratio, eg. vitruvian proportions, or, for comprehensibility, pericean semiotic triad. As living creatures, we all have acute awareness of vestigiality and redundancy. Overdressing signals, by evincing severe mental conflict, the same disgust-self preservation reaction (manifesting as ostracization) as seeing a leper. Thus, gigachad sexcore is not flattering. Neither is looking like a 90's NBA player. Sartorially, such proportional attention means hand craft somewhere in the process, and a baseline of self awareness from a third person perspective on the part of the wearer/consumer. These criteria aren't possible to satisfy with factory mass production or consumer demand/consumer manipulation patterns. People don't dress well because they suffer on a spectrum and cultural heritage of ugliness and failure, a trend present both internally and externally.

What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)
>Horsehair brush ($10-15)
>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4
>Heavy conditioner (if you live in terrible snow/rain areas) Sno seal/Obernauf LP
>Don't forget that boots need time to dry properly, rotate them and don't wear them daily for too long

How do I deal with x stain?
>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

>Should I buy turdsdays/soloshits/doc shitans?
No they are filled with synthetic materials aimed at instant comfort but will not hold up to actual use.
>b-b-but muh ecelebs on youtube said they're good
no. you will waste your time and money and still have uncomfortable footwear at the end of the day. spend the extra $100 and get something real.

>>17418041
Former bartender here. The hillyard doesn't say where the sole is from or what properties it has. How slip-proof is it? We don't know.
Email White's and ask.
Otherwise, we already know the mini Vibram on a lot of their other boots is oil resisting and generally non-slip. I would prefer this sole.

That said, you almost certainly do not need to worry about oil behind the bar. Only way I can think that'd happen is if someone breaks a jar of olives. Beyond that, everywhere I worked, the tiles were grippy enough and I was wearing fryes. Only trouble I had was this one place with granite floors where wet soles would fuck you up.

As far as comfort goes, there's probably rubber mats you're working on, so any sole works, but I hate the mats and would solo bar without them.

A couple toes are crooked but they're slowly looking more normal as the years go by. I might look into toe straighteners, thank you. I'll also look into stretches.
I have a paraffin bath that I use in winter because it's cold, but this year I've been neglecting to do it. I should start that again. My toe cuticles are a mess and I don't know how to make them prettier without risking an infection? Especially in winter. But if I can get that fixed up, I'll run a nail buffer across the nails which will improve the look of the nail 1000%

>>17409222
>then out of nowhere it just collapses and i gain almost all of it back
you're plateauing. everyone has a weight where they plateau - for me it's 105lbs.
>buy digital scale for 20 buckaroos
>avoid shocking your body too early
>incrementally stagger down your calorie deficit over a week
>recoup calories within 2-3 days so that your body doesn't think you're going into starvation mode
>repeat lowering plateau threshold
my original plateau was 106lbs last year, took 4 months to drop it down to 103-104lbs

>money clip for cash

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think it depends on the occasion. A money clip is better than a wallet, if you're wearing a suit. Card holder too. A wallet would create an unpleasant bulge on your suit. A card holder and clip can be hidden in a inner pocket of the jacket.

For everyday usage, I find both to be inconvenient. Especially if you live somewhere, where you often need coins. (like here in Germany) If, however, you live somewhere, where they got rid of cash and you can pay electronically or with card everywhere, by all means just get a card holder. The smaller the better. I'm so sick of being a walking ATM.

>>17421070
>How do I make sure it’s genuine
By doing a lot of research and getting to know the brand and the watches they produced. Seikos for instance all have their reference number on the dial under the 6 o'clock marker and you can work from there.
>what should I usually ask the seller?
Just basic stuff, photos help a ton.
>Should I get a pic of the mechanism?
Not that important, it matters more whether it has been serviced recently or not.
>What should I expect from an accuracy stand point.
Not much to be honest. Mechanical watches, especially older ones, aren't that accurate to begin with, generally they can be brought down to around +/- a minute per day i would say, that i would consider acceptable. I haven't checked mine yet because i rarely wear them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17421825
Imo you should start with basic stuff and slowly try to determine yourself what works and what doesn't, kind of like learning to cook. The infographics on young-stalin.com is outdated (e.g. raw denim, certain boots, arguably menswear in general) but should still be helpful for figuring out what basics to get and where to get them, and a little bit of how to put things together based on stuff like color, silhouette, and texture. Basic outfits should be easy to put together though, and once you have some you can start paying attention to what works and what doesn't, in your own outfits and in those of people around you. Over time you will develop your own eye and not have to rely on much on online guides and stuff to tell you what to wear. If you have more specific questions I can do my best to answer them, but try to read through the sticky and stuff first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17421825
Cultivating your own personal style is the key to dressing "nice and coherent".
It's not about being quirky or a special snowflake, it's about understanding how you want to present yourself to the world
- What is concordant with your interests or personality?

A large component of what triggers the perception of being "well dressed" is wearing garments that fit you properly.
Start by understanding your measurements & looking at others with similar body types
for outfit inspiration (but not emulation).
- Waist, thigh, inseam & rise for pants (what rise hits you high-waisted, for example); chest & lengths (arm, body, back, etc.) for tops.

Once you understand fit you can start branching out into more deliberate aesthetic/silhouette considerations.

Keeping things monochromatic will also benefit you, or, at the very least, pick a palette and try to adhere to it.

- The biggest tip here is accounting for tonality in colors
(e.g. grey with green undertones might conflict with a bright blue shirt, but
look more coherent with a taupe shirt).
Don't obsess over this, but train your eye to spot garments w/ fabric or materials that will match your wardrobe.

Ultimately, dressing nicer - for you individually - should be a consequential time investment;
This contrasted with just blasting your wallet with a bunch of generic basics, which is likely to end in you clogging your
closet with a lot of boring clothes you don't feel good wearing, and ultimately have no attachment to.

Not really. The equivalent is more like a black/white tie dress code. The tang suits and cheongsam commonly associated with Chinese culture are actually Manchurian in origin, forcibly imposed by the Manchu-led Qing dynasty. The hanfu movement is about reviving the native Han Chinese dress of all the dynasties prior as the Chinese ethnic costume, similar to how it's not weird at all for Japanese people to wear kimono at certain culturally significant events.

Fascinate (jp) ships worldwide and has a lot of mandarin neck button-ups and other interesting garments in your price range.
Stocks mostly Japanese brands, shipped worldwide w/ domestic pricing, in addition to various other up-and-coming designers.

You could also check out Mr. Porter / Ssense sales if you're more in the market for hyped brands, artisanal shit, or ultra-luxe.
Norse Store / Haven / Canoe Club also have a lot of garments that fit your specs, albeit all the above definitely lean on the higher price range
and overprice many foreign labels.

Grailed is an obvious one, as well. Play with filters and even just set it to "brand new" if you're not looking to buy used clothes.

>>17420941
NTA but a quick google search shows that the originak breton shirts date from the mid 19th century and had 21 stripes, one for each Napoleon victory. They were worn by sailors because it made them easier to spot if they fell overboard. Later, Coco Chanel used the design in some of her stuff.

I guess that, by extension, you coukd say that any white and blue -or white and any other color- striped shirt could be called a breton shirt as it usually happens in fashion. But if you wanna be a puris, a breton shirt has exactly 21 blue stripes over a white base.
